rdf:about="https://source.data.ox.ac.uk/vacancies/117652/0011854354.pdf">     <rdf:value rdf:datatype="http://purl.org/xtypes/Fragment-PlainText">DEPARTMENT OF PHARMACOLOGY UNIVERSITY OF OXFORD Head of Department Professor Nigel Emptage  Job description and selection criteria Job title Division Department Location Grade and salary Hours Contract type Reporting to Vacancy reference Additional information \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd  European Blaschko Visiting Research Fellowship Medical Sciences Department of Pharmacology Mansfield Road, Oxford OX1 3QT Grade 7: \ufffd\ufffd30,434-\ufffd\ufffd37,394 per annum Full time Fixed-term contract for 2 years \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd funded by the Blaschko Trust Professors Nigel Emptage (Pharmacology) and Peter Brown (MRC Brain Network Dynamics Unit) 117652 \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Applications can only be considered from graduate students in pharmacology or related areas of study resident outside of the UK, preference will be given to students resident in Continental Europe due to the terms of the Blaschko Trust. This post is available to start on 1 October 2015  Committed to equality and valuing diversity The University of Oxford holds a Bronze Athena Swan award. The Athena Swan programme supports good employment practices for women in Science, Engineering and Technology (SET). Page 1 of 5  Introduction The University The University of Oxford is a complex and stimulating organisation, which enjoys an international reputation as a world-class centre of excellence in research and teaching. It employs over 10,000 staff and has a student population of over 21,000. Most staff are directly appointed and managed by one of the University\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds 130 departments or other units within a highly devolved operational structure - this includes 5,900 \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdacademicrelated\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd staff (postgraduate research, computing, senior library, and administrative staff) and 2,820 \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdsupport\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd staff (including clerical, library, technical, and manual staff). There are also over 1,600 academic staff (professors, readers, lecturers), whose appointments are in the main overseen by a combination of broader divisional and local faculty board/departmental structures. Academics are generally all also employed by one of the 38 constituent colleges of the University as well as by the central University itself. Our annual income in 2010/11 was \ufffd\ufffd919.6m. Oxford is one of Europe's most innovative and entrepreneurial universities: income from external research contracts exceeds \ufffd\ufffd376m p.a., and more than 70 spin-off companies have been created. For more information please visit www.ox.ac.uk Medical Sciences Division The Medical Sciences Division is an internationally recognised centre of excellence for biomedical and clinical research and teaching, and the largest academic division in the University of Oxford. It includes 15 clinical departments and 5 non-clinical departments. World-leading programmes, housed in state-of-the-art facilities, cover the full range of scientific endeavour from the molecule to the population. With our NHS partners we also foster the highest possible standards in patient care. For more information please visit www.medsci.ox.ac.uk Department of Pharmacology The Department of Pharmacology is based in the University\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds science area in the centre of Oxford. The Department houses around 180 researchers, postgraduate students and support staff, and has excellent facilities.The members of the Department, associated staff and visiting scientists are all engaged in the investigation of basic questions concerning the interaction of chemical substances with biological systems. Research in the Department is focused on cell signalling, cardiovascular pharmacology, ion channel and molecular pharmacology and neuropharmacology. In many of these areas the Department plays a leading role in the international pharmacological community. The research of the Department has consistently been given a very high ranking in the Government\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds assessments of research in Universities and was rated first in the UK for PreClinical Sciences in the 2008 Research Assessment Exercise. For more information please visit: www.pharm.ox.ac.uk Page 2 of 5  Medical Research Council, Brain Network Dynamics Unit The Unit is attached to the Department and seven groups in the Unit (see www.mrc.ox.ac.uk) study chemical transmitters and synaptic connections of identified neurones in the vertebrate central nervous system. They analyse neuronal networks in relation to the functioning of the central nervous system in health and rodent disease models. In particular, the programmes define and explain neuronal diversity in two systems of major mental health concern, the cerebral cortex and the basal ganglia. In order to define molecular modules, which correspond to particular cellular functions as sets of co-localised, interacting proteins microscopic and molecular methods are used. Each programme defines the interactions of identified cells in these systems, as they affect functioning of the organism at all levels, from molecular microdomains to behaviour. Linacre College There are 38 self-governing and independent colleges at Oxford, giving both academic staff and students the benefits of belonging to a small, interdisciplinary community as well as to a large, internationally-renowned institution. The collegiate system fosters a strong sense of community, bringing together leading academics and students across subjects, and from different cultures and countries. Linacre is a vibrant and progressive post-graduate College of Oxford University. All 450 students of the College have completed a first degree and are now studying for an advanced qualification. Linacre's prime objective is to provide the best possible environment, both intellectual and social, for its Fellows and graduate students. The College is housed in fine buildings, most of which were purpose-built, on St Cross Road, surrounded on three sides by parks and playing fields, in a convenient location on the edge of the University Science Area and within easy reach of all the main University Departments and Libraries. The College has a number of modern teaching and seminar rooms, a well-equipped gym and small but exquisite gardens. There are some 50 Fellows, the majority of whom are Professors, Readers, and Lecturers in a wide range of University Faculties. The Fellowship includes some of Oxford's most distinguished scholars. About half the student body is from overseas, representing over 50 countries; they are divided almost equally between the sciences, arts and humanities. Linacre was one of the first Colleges in Oxford to accept both men and women on an equal basis. It is unusual among Oxford Colleges in having no senior common room. The Fellows, staff and students share the same facilities and eat together in the dining hall in order to cultivate an egalitarian academic community. The College is family-friendly and has a strong environmental ethos. Junior Research Fellowships at Linacre are non-stipendiary but Fellows receive an annual \ufffd\ufffd300 research allowance and are entitled to free lunches and dinners in College when the College kitchens are open. They may also apply for small grants to assist with conference travel. Fellows are expected to co-operate in the running of the College. The main commitment is to act as an adviser to a small number of graduate students. Linacre is not able to offer Fellows personal study-bedrooms in College but they may reserve rooms for tutorials, seminars, social functions, and to accommodate guests. Further information about the College can be found on the website: www.linacre.ox.ac.uk  Page 3 of 5  Overview of the role The successful applicant can join any one of the research groups in the Department of Pharmacology (http://www.pharm.ox.ac.uk/) including the MRC Brain Network Dynamics Unit (www.mrc.ox.ac.uk/) depending on their interests. Candidates in their final year of doctoral studies are eligible provided they submit their doctoral thesis before taking up the Fellowship. The Fellowship is for two years from 1 October 2015 and is attached to Linacre College where the Visiting Fellow may reside and have full rights and access to facilities. Those unfamiliar with the research of the Department and MRC Unit should look up the scientific areas on the websites and are welcome to liaise with any of the academic group leaders.  Responsibilities/duties 1. Manage own academic research and administrative activities. This involves small-scale project management, to co-ordinate multiple aspects of work in order to meet deadlines. 2. Test hypotheses and analyse scientific data from a variety of sources, reviewing and refining working hypotheses as appropriate. 3. Adapt existing and develop new scientific techniques and experimental protocols. 4. Contribute ideas for new research projects. 5. Develop ideas for generating research income, and present detailed research proposals to senior researchers. 6. Collaborate in the preparation of scientific reports and journal articles and occasionally present papers and posters. 7. Act as a source of information and advice to other members of the group on scientific protocols and experimental techniques. 8. Represent the research group at external meetings/seminars, either with other members of the group or alone. 9. Carry out collaborative projects with colleagues in partner institutions, and research groups. 10. Responsibilities may also include: supervision of project students; carrying out any appropriate administrative duties associated with the work; contributing to the general running of the laboratory. The Fellow will also have an opportunity to contribute 2 hours per week teaching on a voluntary basis.  Selection criteria Essential 1 Have, or expect to obtain through the submission of their thesis by the time of the interview, a PhD in an appropriate science (eg Pharmacology, Physiology, Medicine, Physics, Computing, Neuroscience). 2 Evidence that highlights previous duties (either in study or work environment) that require: (i) Accuracy and attention to detail. (ii) Methodical work. (iii) Reliability. (iv) Competence with computers skills. Page 4 of 5  3  (vi) Ability to participate in scientific discussion within the group Experience of basic laboratory management, including awareness of Health and Safety issues and ordering of consumables.  Desirable 1 Publications in the area of research interest, commensurate with stage of academic career. 2 Home office licence and in-vivo surgery skills 3 Demonstrated ability to contribute to teaching through seminars and practicals  Working at the University of Oxford For further information about working at Oxford, please see: http://www.ox.ac.uk/about_the_university/jobs/research/  How to apply If you consider that you meet the selection criteria, click on the Apply Now button on the \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdJob Details\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd page and follow the on-screen instructions to register as a user. You will then be required to complete a number of screens with your application details, relating to your skills and experience. When prompted, please provide details of two referees and indicate whether we can contact them at this stage. You will also be required to upload a CV and supporting statement. Your application will be judged solely on the basis of how you demonstrate that that you meet the selection criteria outlined above and we are happy to consider evidence of transferable skills or experience which you may have gained outside the context of paid employment or education. You should also consider which group within either the Department of Pharmacology (http://www.pharm.ox.ac.uk/) or the MRC Brain Network Dynamics Unit (www.mrc.ox.ac.uk/) you would like to work in should you be successful. Please make sure that you include this information on your application. Please save all uploaded documents to show your name and the document type. All applications must be received by midday on the closing date stated in the online advertisement. Should you experience any difficulties using the online application system, please email recruitment.support@admin.ox.ac.uk. To return to the online application at any stage, please click on the following link www.recruit.ox.ac.uk Please note that you will be notified of the progress of your application by automatic e-mails from our e-recruitment system. Please check your spam/junk mail regularly to ensure that you receive all e-mails. </rdf:Description>   <rdf:Description rdf:about="https://data.ox.ac.uk/id/vacancy/117652">     <rdfs:comment rdf:datatype="http://purl.org/xtypes/Fragment-XHTML"><div xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> This fellowship is fixed-term for 2 years from 1 October 2015 and is attached to Linacre College where the visiting fellow may reside and have full rights and access to facilities.  <br/><br/>The Blaschko Fellow will manage their own academic research and administrative activities including testing hypotheses, analysing scientific data, developing new scientific techniques, and contributing ideas for new research projects.<br/><br/>Successful applicants will be expected to demonstrate:<br/><br/>- that they have, or expect to obtain through the submission of their thesis by the time of the interview, a PhD in an appropriate science;<br/>- evidence that highlights accuracy and attention to detail, methodical work, reliability, competence with computer skills, and the ability to participate in scientific discussion within the group;<br/>- experience of basic laboratory management, including awareness of health and safety issues and ordering of consumables.<br/><br/>The fellowship will provide a salary of &#163;30,434 - &#163;37,394 p.a., college fees and an award of &#163;2,000 p.a. for travel to conferences and laboratory expenses.<br/><br/>The successful applicant can join any one of the research groups in the Department of Pharmacology (<a href="http://www.pharm.ox.ac.uk" target="_blank">www.pharm.ox.ac.uk</a>) including the MRC Brain Network Dynamics Unit (<a href="http://www.mrc.ox.ac.uk" target="_blank">www.mrc.ox.ac.uk</a>) depending on their interests - applicants should specify which group they would like to work with in their application. <br/><br/>Applications can only be considered from graduate students in pharmacology or related areas of study resident outside of the UK, preference will be given to students resident in Continental Europe due to the terms of the Blaschko Trust.<br/><br/>The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on Wednesday 8 April 2015. </div> </rdfs:comment>   </rdf:Description>   <rdf:Description rdf:about="http://xmlns.com/foaf/0.1/name">     <rdf:type rdf:resource="http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#DatatypeProperty"/>   </rdf:Description>   <rdf:Description rdf:about="http://oxpoints.oucs.ox.ac.uk/id/00000000">     <lyou:business-incubation rdf:resource="http://www.isis-innovation.com/"/>   </rdf:Description>   <rdf:Description rdf:about="https://data.ox.ac.uk/id/vacancy/117436">     <rdfs:comment>Applications are invited to join a multidisciplinary team at the MRC Unit in the Department of Pharmacology, University of Oxford. We seek a Postdoctoral Neuroscientist to develop, execute and analyse a combination of in vivo electrophysiological, behavioural and optogenetics experiments in rodents as part of a scientific project that is designed to elucidate the normal functions of midbrain dopaminergic neurons as well as their dysfunction in models of Parkinson\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds disease. Interested candidates should hold a PhD or equivalent qualification (or MD) in a relevant area of research, and should have a promising track record in original research in their particular field of neuroscience. Candidates are also expected to have some technical expertise in neurophysiology, and to provide evidence of creative and critical thinking as applied to the advancement and delivery of a focused and cohesive programme of research.The postholder will work with Professor Peter J Magill and Dr Paul D Dodson at the MRC Unit, Department of Pharmacology. The group uses a transdisciplinary approach to elucidate the function and dysfunction of the basal ganglia, and employs innovative electrophysiological, anatomical, behavioural and genetics-based techniques to study these circuits in reduced preparations and the whole organism.This is a fixed-term post of 32 months, funded by the Medical Research Foundation, with an initial probationary period, to start on 1 June 2015 or as soon as possible thereafter.The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on Friday 24 April 2015.</rdfs:comment>   </rdf:Description>   <rdf:Description the Medical Research Foundation Professor Peter J Magill and Dr Paul D Dodson 117436 This post is available from 1 June 2015  Reporting to Vacancy reference Additional information  Committed to equality and valuing diversity The University of Oxford holds a Bronze Athena Swan award. The Athena Swan programme supports good employment practices for women in Science, Engineering and Technology (SET).  Introduction The University The University of Oxford is a complex and stimulating organisation, which enjoys an international reputation as a world-class centre of excellence in research and teaching. It employs over 10,000 staff and has a student population of over 21,000. Most staff are directly appointed and managed by one of the University\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds 130 departments or other units within a highly devolved operational structure - this includes 5,900 \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdacademic-related\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd staff (postgraduate research, computing, senior library, and administrative staff) and 2,820 \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdsupport\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd staff (including clerical, library, technical, and manual staff). There are also over 1,600 academic staff (professors, readers, lecturers), whose appointments are in the main overseen by a combination of broader divisional and local faculty board/departmental structures. Academics are generally all also employed by one of the 38 constituent colleges of the University as well as by the central University itself. Our annual income in 2010/11 was \ufffd\ufffd919.6m. Oxford is one of Europe's most innovative and entrepreneurial universities: income from external research contracts exceeds \ufffd\ufffd376m p.a., and more than 70 spin-off companies have been created. For more information please visit www.ox.ac.uk Medical Sciences Division The Medical Sciences Division is an internationally recognised centre of excellence for biomedical and clinical research and teaching, and the largest academic division in the University of Oxford. It includes 15 clinical departments and 5 non-clinical departments. World-leading programmes, housed in state-of-the-art facilities, cover the full range of scientific endeavour from the molecule to the population. With our NHS partners we also foster the highest possible standards in patient care. For more information please visit www.medsci.ox.ac.uk Department of Pharmacology The Department of Pharmacology is based in the University\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds science area in the centre of Oxford. The Department houses around 180 researchers, postgraduate students and support staff, and has excellent facilities. The members of the Department, associated staff and visiting scientists are all engaged in the investigation of basic questions concerning the interaction of chemical substances with biological systems. Research in the Department is focused on cell signalling, cardiovascular pharmacology, ion channel and molecular pharmacology and neuropharmacology. In many of these areas the Department plays a leading role in the international pharmacological community. The research of the Department has consistently been given a very high ranking in the Government\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds assessments of research in Universities and was rated first in the UK for Pre-Clinical Sciences in the 2008 Research Assessment Exercise. For more information please visit: www.pharm.ox.ac.uk MRC Unit In 1984, the Medical Research Council established the Anatomical Neuropharmacology Unit attached to the University Department of Pharmacology at Oxford under the Honorary Directorship of Professor A David Smith with Dr Peter Somogyi as Associate Director. The Unit started operation in 1985 and in 1998 Professor Somogyi became Director. Total membership of the Unit, including postgraduate research students and those on external grants, is usually about thirty five to forty at any one time. The Unit's terms of reference are: \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd To study chemical transmitters and synaptic connections of identified neurons in the vertebrate central nervous system; \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd To analyse neuronal networks in relation to the functioning of the central nervous system in health and disease. The mission of the Unit is to define the molecular, spatial and temporal organisational principles of networks in the brain at the synaptic and cellular level by analysing a variety of brain regions  Page 2 of 6  affected in disease. The ability to develop an understanding of the cellular mechanisms underlying activity in a range of neuronal centres is essential, since insight from one area provides hypotheses and facilitates progress in another. This strategy also aids the discovery of general principles of operation and the definition of local adaptations. Brain areas studied at present include the cerebellum, the basal ganglia, the cerebral cortex and, in particular, the hippocampal formation. Neuronal systems are chosen for exploration on the basis of their importance for the Medical Research Council's strategy and on the internationally competitive scientific strengths of senior scientists. The sharing of ideas, expertise, facilities and the numerous in-house collaborations make the programmes very cost effective. The Unit combines physiological, pharmacological and anatomical analyses, both at the level of systems and the single neuron or synapse. Neurons are identified in terms of their molecular composition and synaptic connections both locally and with distant brain regions, as well as their electrical activity in response to inputs or in behavioural tests. In the same experiment, electrophysiology, immunocytochemistry, light and electron microscopy are combined to characterise identified cells. Revealing the transmitters and their receptors at the synapses of such characterised neurons helps to explain how neural networks determine behaviour, and how drugs act to influence behaviour. Studies on the intracellular trafficking and biochemical modification of neurotransmitter receptors identify key steps in the dynamic regulation of synaptic transmission. Human brain tissue is also studied to establish what changes occur in disease. The realisation that many disorders of the brain may manifest as errors in the co-ordination of neuronal assemblies, several of the groups have been collaborating to develop a chronocircuitry of the basal ganglia and the hippocampus. This is a long-term goal that requires large-scale recording of brain state dependent activity and temporal relationships amongst rigorously defined neuronal types. The Unit has pioneered novel approaches to the study of the central nervous system and has developed innovative methods and concepts to explain the operation of complex neuronal networks. These methods and concepts are disseminated both in the UK and internationally, and have contributed to the wider development of neuroscience. The Unit provides a stimulating environment for training postgraduate research students and scientists at all levels, both from the UK and overseas and some of our alumni have become World leaders (click for alumni list). Senior scientists are involved in extensive collaborations with academic institutes and companies in the UK and abroad (click for collaborators list). These interactions provide intellectual and technical enrichment for the Unit and greatly expand the resources of the programmes. For more information please visit: www.mrc.ox.ac.uk or www.mrcbndu.ox.ac.uk.  Page 3 of 6  Overview of the role Applications are invited for a Postdoctoral Neuroscientist to develop, execute and analyse a combination of in-vivo electrophysiological, behavioural and optogenetics experiments in rodents as part of a scientific project that is designed to elucidate the normal functions of dopaminergic neurons as well as their dysfunction in models of Parkinson\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds disease. In addition to having a PhD (or MD) or equivalent qualification in a relevant discipline, candidates should have a promising track record of original research in their particular field of neuroscience and be able to demonstrate creative and critical thinking as applied to the development and execution of a focused programme of research. Candidates are also expected to have expertise in electrophysiology (either in vitro or in vivo). The post holder will work with Professor Peter Magill and Dr Paul Dodson in a multidisciplinary team based in the MRC Unit, Department of Pharmacology. The MRC Unit has a strong track record in studying the organization and functional properties of the neuronal networks of the basal ganglia in normal rodents and in models of Parkinson\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds disease. The team uses a transdisciplinary approach to elucidate the function and dysfunction of the basal ganglia, employing innovative techniques electrophysiological, anatomical, behavioural and genetics-based techniques. The proposed research will take full advantage of the intellectual environment, capital equipment, technical expertise and excellent infrastructure in place in the Unit, and there will be ample opportunity to work in partnership with other Unit groups. This is a fixed-term post of 32 months, with an initial probationary period, to start on 1 June 2015 or as soon as possible thereafter. This post is a University Grade 7 (07S) position with a starting salary of between \ufffd\ufffd30,434 and \ufffd\ufffd33,242 per annum (commensurate with experience). This appointment is to conduct research and provide specialist expertise related to the research programme outlined above, which is dependent on a time-limited external research grant of 32 months (from the Medical Research Foundation) and for which there is no expectation that the work will continue beyond the availability of that external funding  Responsibilities/duties The overall purpose of this post is to conduct original research, provide specialist expertise, and communicate empirical discoveries, as part of a scientific programme that is designed to elucidate the function and dysfunction of midbrain dopaminergic neurons in rodents. The post holder will report to Professor Peter Magill and Dr Paul Dodson. The post holder will not be expected to line-manage anyone. Main duties and responsibilities of the post holder: 1. Deliver a focused programme of research that uses electrophysiological and behavioural analyses to elucidate the function of dopaminergic neurons, and their dysfunction in rodent models of Parkinson\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds disease. This will include the design, execution and reporting of his/her own experiments and, when appropriate, the introduction and development of new approaches and technologies in pursuit of the scientific goals of the programme. 2. Conduct electrophysiological experiments in anaesthetised and behaving mice to analyse the function/dysfunction of midbrain dopaminergic neurons and associated brain structures. 3. Undertake in vivo analyses of the function/dysfunction of dopaminergic neurons and associated brain structures using advanced genetics-based approaches (including optogenetics, pharmacogenetics and other viral vector-mediated cell labeling/manipulation techniques), combining them with electrophysiological recordings. 4. Analyse and interpret data generated from the electrophysiological and behavioural studies, ensuring that scientific data is of the highest quality and in a form for further mining, publication, archiving and presentation. 5. Communicate the results of the experiments in the form of original research papers for publication in international peer-reviewed journals, as well as in the form of presentations at scientific meetings and lectures/seminars within the MRC Unit and at other institutions. 6. Collaborate on projects with other groups within the MRC Unit, and with external collaborators, as appropriate. 7. Undertake the training and supervision of students, technical staff, other host group members, and visiting scientists in his/her areas of expertise when appropriate.  Page 4 of 6  8.  The key responsibilities of the post holder include: (1) Make effective contribution to science of host group; (2) Work with foresight and imagination; (3) Ensure good level of productivity by managing own workload and delivering relevant scientific results; (4) Communicate effectively with supervisor in scientific and administrative matters; (5) Adhere to statutory regulations e.g. Health & Safety, Animals (Scientific Procedures) Act, IT/data security; and (6) Assist in host group\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds public engagement and communication activities.  Job description Research topic Principal Investigator / supervisor Project web site Funding partner Technical skills Neurobiology of the basal ganglia Professor Peter J Magill www.mrc.ox.ac.uk or www.mrcbndu.ox.ac.uk Medical Research Foundation Neurophysiology, optogenetics/pharmacogenetics, behavioural training/analysis  Selection criteria Essential \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Education, qualifications and training: PhD (or MD) or equivalent qualification in a relevant area of research. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Previous work experience: Laboratory experience in electrophysiological techniques as applied to the scientific investigation of the nervous system. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Knowledge: Expertise in the analysis and interpretation of electrophysiological data. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Research profile: Demonstrable record of originality, creativity and productivity in neuroscience research. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Research delivery: Evidence of executing a focused and cohesive programme of research. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Personal skills/qualities: The post holder should be capable of independent decision making and collaboration with research colleagues. Desirable \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Postdoctoral research experience. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Experience of electrophysiological recordings in vivo. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Experience of working with wildtype and genetically-altered mice. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Experience of optogenetics, pharmacogenetics or similar approaches. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Experience of analysing rodent behaviour and/or of the behavioural training of rodents. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Experience with the use of MATLAB software. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Track record of research in the basal ganglia. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Experience of advising and training junior members of a research team and/or interacting with external collaborators. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Published at least one original research paper as a first author. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Evidence of problem solving skills, and using personal initiative to generate and pursue own ideas through research. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd Evidence of giving invited talks and seminars to research groups.  Page 5 of 6  Working at the University of Oxford For further information about working at Oxford, please see: http://www.ox.ac.uk/about_the_university/jobs/research/  Work-life balance and family-friendly policies at the University of Oxford The University aims to support all employees with parental or caring responsibilities to ensure that they are able to balance work and family life. This website (http://www.admin.ox.ac.uk/eop/parentsandcarersinformation/ ) provides a hub of information for all parents and carers, with links to university policies, procedures and guidance, as well as details of the facilities and benefits offered to mothers, fathers and guardians of children. In addition, the website highlights university policies, as well as external sources of guidance. You are advised to read the university policies in full; and to see respective guidance on the Personnel Services website for full details. Views expressed on external websites are not necessarily endorsed by the University of Oxford.  How to apply If you consider that you meet the selection criteria, click on the Apply Now button on the \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdJob Details\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd page and follow the on-screen instructions to register as a user. You will then be required to complete a number of screens with your application details, relating to your skills and experience. When prompted, please provide details of two referees and indicate whether we can contact them at this stage. You will also be required to upload a CV and supporting statement. The supporting statement should describe what you have been doing over at least the last 10 years. This may have been employment, education, or you may have taken time away from these activities in order to raise a family, care for a dependant, or travel for example. Your application will be judged solely on the basis of how you demonstrate that that you meet the selection criteria outlined above and we are happy to consider evidence of transferable skills or experience which you may have gained outside the context of paid employment or education. Please save all uploaded documents to show your name and the document type. All applications must be received by midday on the closing date stated in the online advertisement. Should you experience any difficulties using the online application system, please email recruitment.support@admin.ox.ac.uk To return to the online application at any stage, please click on the following link www.recruit.ox.ac.uk Please note that you will be notified of the progress of your application by automatic e-mails from our e-recruitment system. Please check your spam/junk mail regularly to ensure that you receive all e-mails. <vacancy:furtherParticulars rdf:resource="https://source.data.ox.ac.uk/vacancies/117436/0011831605.pdf"/>     <rdfs:comment rdf:datatype="http://purl.org/xtypes/Fragment-XHTML"><div xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> Applications are invited to join a multidisciplinary team at the MRC Unit in the Department of Pharmacology, University of Oxford. We seek a Postdoctoral Neuroscientist to develop, execute and analyse a combination of in vivo electrophysiological, behavioural and optogenetics experiments in rodents as part of a scientific project that is designed to elucidate the normal functions of midbrain dopaminergic neurons as well as their dysfunction in models of Parkinson&#8217;s disease. Interested candidates should hold a PhD or equivalent qualification (or MD) in a relevant area of research, and should have a promising track record in original research in their particular field of neuroscience. Candidates are also expected to have some technical expertise in neurophysiology, and to provide evidence of creative and critical thinking as applied to the advancement and delivery of a focused and cohesive programme of research.<br/><br/>The postholder will work with Professor Peter J Magill and Dr Paul D Dodson at the MRC Unit, Department of Pharmacology. The group uses a transdisciplinary approach to elucidate the function and dysfunction of the basal ganglia, and employs innovative electrophysiological, anatomical, behavioural and genetics-based techniques to study these circuits in reduced preparations and the whole organism.  <br/><br/>This is a fixed-term post of 32 months, funded by the Medical Research Foundation, with an initial probationary period, to start on 1 June 2015 or as soon as possible thereafter.  <br/><br/>The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on Friday 24 April 2015. </div> </rdfs:comment>
